G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the cause of action arose in Worcester, Massachusetts, and Defendant’s property giving rise to the injury is located there.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 17.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful visitor, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the maintenance of the premises, including the sidewalk, pursuant to Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 84, § 17 and related provisions.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner who undertakes snow and ice removal must do so with reasonable care and cannot create or fail to remedy a hazardous condition that foreseeably endangers lawful visitors.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that Massachusetts abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and applies the ordinary reasonable care standard to snow and ice, expressly including situations where an owner undertakes removal. It also criticizes a prior rule that could absolve owners even when their removal efforts "foreseeably increase the risk of mishap" and reaffirms that once a person undertakes to mitigate a hazard, they must use reasonable care and avoid creating or leaving a dangerous condition. Thus it directly supports that an owner who undertakes snow and ice removal must act with reasonable care and not create or fail to remedy a foreseeable hazard to lawful visitors.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. … [O]nce a person acts to mitigate a potential hazard to another, he will be liable for harm resulting from a failure to exercise reasonable care.”

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty of reasonable care under all the circumstances on an owner or possessor of land.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case that abolished the common‑law invitee/licensee distinction and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers under the circumstances, at least to lawful entrants. Although the quoted passage is from a concurrence criticizing the treatment of trespassers, the majority opinion clearly states that the occupier’s duty is one of reasonable care in all the circumstances and no longer turns on the invitee/licensee labels. Thus the case supports the proposition about Massachusetts law imposing a duty of reasonable care on land possessors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt:
[From the majority opinion, not in the excerpt provided]
"We therefore hold that the usual rules of negligence are to determine the liability of an occupier of land for injuries sustained by persons coming on the land with the occupier’s consent. The test is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others, and the burden of proof is on the person injured to establish the occupier’s negligence."

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant was on notice of the dangerous condition as evidenced by tenant reports and photographs, satisfying both actual and constructive notice requirements under *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973), and *Thorson v. Mandell*, 402 Mass. 744 (1988).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: Oliveri deals with whether circumstantial evidence about the condition of a foreign substance on stairs was sufficient to prove that it had been present long enough to put the defendant on constructive notice. It does not involve tenant reports, photographs, or any form of prior complaints, nor does it discuss how such reports would establish actual or constructive notice. The case actually finds the evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant, so it does not support a proposition that notice was satisfied by prior reports and photographs.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

*Thorson v. Mandell*, 402 Mass. 744 (198.proposition: Defendant was on notice of the dangerous condition as evidenced by tenant reports and photographs, satisfying both actual and constructive notice requirements under *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973), and *Thorson v. Mandell*, 402 Mass. 744 (1988).
*Thorson v. Mandell*, 402 Mass. 744 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss tenant reports, photographs, or actual/constructive notice of a dangerous condition. As to the YWCA, the court explicitly finds there was no defective property condition and no duty to warn of an obvious risk created by the rehearsal participants themselves; the case turns on lack of duty and obviousness of risk, not notice of a premises defect. Thus, *Thorson v. Mandell* does not support a proposition about satisfying actual and constructive notice requirements through tenant reports and photographs.
*Thorson v. Mandell*, 402 Mass. 744 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Thorson makes no claim before us, however, that the YWCA’s auditorium was not in reasonably safe condition. Nor does she claim that the YWCA did anything to cause her injury… The condition that caused Thorson’s injury was not created by the YWCA. That condition was created by Mandell and other people participating in the rehearsal. The risk was inherent in the dance step attempted and obvious to the participants.”

*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.proposition: The failure to remediate the icy condition after actual notice constitutes negligence under *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992), and *Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass. 362 (1980).
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.support_reasoning: Aylward holds that, as a matter of law, the defendants were not negligent for failing to remove a natural accumulation of snow and ice, and affirms summary judgment for the landowners. The opinion explicitly rejects the idea that merely failing to remediate such a natural icy condition constitutes negligence absent some additional act or omission creating a defect. It therefore does not support the proposition that failure to remediate the icy condition after actual notice constitutes negligence; rather, it limits liability in natural-accumulation cases.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There is no evidence in this case which would allow a jury to find that the defendants failed to exercise reasonable care in the circumstances and created a defective condition on their property. In the absence of such evidence, there is no evidence of negligence by the McCloskeys… We do not suggest that an accumulation of snow and ice on one’s property can never be a hazardous or defective condition… In the present case, there is no contention that any defect existed on the property, beyond the mere presence of naturally accumulated snow and ice.”

*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.proposition: The failure to remediate the icy condition after actual notice constitutes negligence under *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992), and *Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass. 362 (1980).
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns negligent design of an automobile, evidentiary rulings, damages (including interest and tax instructions), and excessiveness of the verdict. It does not involve premises liability, snow and ice, or any duty to remediate an icy condition after notice. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses the standard in Aylward v. McCloskey or any analogous duty to remediate icy conditions, so citing Griffin for that proposition is inaccurate.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.relevant_excerpt:
The plaintiff’s automobile, manufactured by the defendant, caught fire while she was driving it, and she was severely burned. On a theory of negligent design, a jury has awarded her $1,000,000 in damages… The defendant’s appeal presents evidentiary issues, issues with respect to the instructions to the jury, and a claim that the damages awarded are excessive…

…We conclude that the judge did not abuse his discretion. There was evidence to support a finding that there would be substantial loss of earning capacity in the future. More important, there was evidence of enormous pain and suffering…

*Jenco v. Town of Reading*, 380 Mass. 54.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable and careless given the foreseeability of harm, contrary to the principles stated in *Jenco v. Town of Reading*, 380 Mass. 540 (1980), and *Souza v. Pratico*, 456 Mass. 1005 (2010).
*Jenco v. Town of Reading*, 380 Mass. 54.case_name: CUNA Mutual Insurance Society v. Attorney General
*Jenco v. Town of Reading*, 380 Mass. 54.support_reasoning: The opinion in Jenco v. Town of Reading concerns the Attorney General’s authority under G.L. c. 93A to issue and enforce a civil investigative demand and the standards for interlocutory appellate review. It does not discuss negligence, foreseeability of harm, or whether a defendant’s conduct was unreasonable or careless. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition about unreasonable conduct given foreseeability of harm.
*Jenco v. Town of Reading*, 380 Mass. 54.relevant_excerpt: "The insubstantiality of CUNA Mutual’s arguments can be demonstrated simply by an analysis of the language of G. L. c. 93A, § 6. ‘The attorney general, whenever he believes a person has engaged in or is engaging in any method, act or practice declared to be unlawful by this chapter, may conduct an investigation to ascertain whether in fact such person has engaged in or is engaging in such method, act or practice.’"

*Souza v. Pratico*, 456 Mass. 1005 (2010.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable and careless given the foreseeability of harm, contrary to the principles stated in *Jenco v. Town of Reading*, 380 Mass. 540 (1980), and *Souza v. Pratico*, 456 Mass. 1005 (2010).
*Souza v. Pratico*, 456 Mass. 1005 (2010.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a petition for extraordinary relief under G.L. c. 211, § 3, dealing with procedural issues about discovery, docket entries, and availability of alternative remedies. It does not discuss standards of negligence, foreseeability of harm, or whether a defendant’s conduct was unreasonable or careless. The case therefore does not provide authority for the negligence/foreseeability proposition for which it is cited.
*Souza v. Pratico*, 456 Mass. 1005 (2010.relevant_excerpt: "The petitioner has failed to satisfy his burden under that rule of *1006showing the lack of an adequate alternative remedy. In the event the petitioner’s motion for a new trial is denied, he may challenge the denial of his discovery motion in a gatekeeper petition, G. L. c. 278, § 33E, and, if that petition were to be allowed, in an appeal to this court."

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 15 and 17.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 84, §§ 15 and 17, landowners in control of abutting sidewalks have a statutory obligation not to permit unsafe accumulations of snow and ice that cause injury.

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: Defendant’s failure to treat the sidewalk appropriately created and maintained an unreasonably dangerous condition, in violation of Massachusetts common law principles of negligence as articulated in *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980), and *Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142 (1993).
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki squarely holds that Massachusetts landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to unreasonable risks of harm on the leased premises, and that a landlord can be liable in negligence to a tenant’s guest for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of the rented area. The case thus articulates and applies the common‑law negligence principle that a landlord’s failure to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition—here, a defective porch railing—can constitute an unreasonably dangerous condition giving rise to liability, which matches the proposition’s use of Young as negligence authority.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk… Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well… Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant.”

*Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142.proposition: Defendant’s failure to treat the sidewalk appropriately created and maintained an unreasonably dangerous condition, in violation of Massachusetts common law principles of negligence as articulated in *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980), and *Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142 (1993).
*Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a municipality’s negligence in failing to protect a student from lacrosse balls on school premises, not a defendant’s treatment of a sidewalk or sidewalk condition. While it reaffirms a common-law duty to provide reasonably safe premises (citing Whitney, Mullins, Irwin), it does not articulate or apply negligence principles specific to maintaining a sidewalk in an unreasonably dangerous condition. Thus, using Alter v. Newton as authority for sidewalk-specific negligence is inaccurate, though it generally supports a duty to keep school premises reasonably safe.
*Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142.relevant_excerpt: “Because of the relationship between a school and its students, the city had a duty of care to the plaintiff to provide her with reasonably safe school premises. … Accordingly, unless each of the failures alleged by the plaintiffs fell within the discretionary function exception, or, unless the city showed a policy reason for not choosing any means to protect its students, the city would not have been entitled to summary judgment.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award statutory interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
